They also said a trial period will not take place in August and September.Ideas, revealed by the town council in an online questionnaire on Friday, includes a pedestrianised ldquosafe space on Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout, including the bottom of Lower Glebe Street.Other plans for Windsor Road could include ldquoshared spaces between pedestrians and traffic during set times, while another included only allowing service traffic ndash such as delivery vehicles ndash to access Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street.One of the major points for discussion is around proposals for a one-way traffic system incorporating Albert Road, Stanwell Road, Hickman Road, Arcot Street,Glebe Street and Ludlow Lane.The grey area marks the safe space pedestrianised proposal.The town council say the one-way system would enable more chevron parking on Plassey Street, Albert Road and Stanwell Road.Ceri McCann, Rachel Came and Karen Hatton at Andrearsquos Flower Boutique on Glebe Street, think the town will sufferpedestrianisation plans go ahead.: Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" alt"Penarth Times: : Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe Street" class"editor-image": Karen Hatton, Ceri McCann and Rachel Came at Andreas Flower Boutique, Glebe StreetldquoPenarth isnrsquot the type of place you come to and spend a day, itrsquos a place people come and park up and quickly do some shopping, they said. ldquoBusinesses are already feeling the impact of lower footfall due to the social distancing parking trials, and to add this to the mix is poor timing.The plans also include additional bus stops, including one right outside Joan Painesrsquo funeral directors.The new ideas are designed to bring an additional  spaces to the town centre, but this is likely to affect residentsShe says buses stopping outside her shop every half an hour - combined with the one-way system - would be likely to cause too much congestion.ldquoMy main concern is the congestion and the impact that will have on my customers, she said. ldquoIt is not nice to have so much noise, fumes, and congestion outside when yoursquore trying to sort out a funeral.Joan and Tony Paines have made a blown up version of the main town area, so people can better understand the ideas.Ms Paines suggested a bus terminal at Station Approach, and said she thinks a one-way system around the town will also cause heavy traffic on smaller roads such as Railway Terrace, Grove Terrace and Woodland Place.Resident and member of Friendsof the Earth Barry andVale Max Wallis said he is in support of partial pedestrianisation, but questioned the one-way system idea.Mr Wallis said that a one-way system would ldquoworsen traffic and add to town centre pollution, adding: ldquoCovid- will force new thinking. People see the benefits of more walking and cycling. Some shops and businesses will close, with more online shopping. The town centre must become more a meeting and activity place access by bus or bike is more attractive withthe reduced traffic.       ,params: .pushMax WallisStrategic consultant John Jackson, who lives in Penarth, is in favour of partial pedestrianisation of Windsor Road on a trial basis.ldquoThis system works abroad, and works abroad in places where the weather isnrsquot always nice, he said. ldquoI think Penarth needs to be a more attractive environment post lockdown, and that would involve some sort of pedestrianisation.ldquoI think the idea to close off Windsor Road from Lower Glebe Street to the roundabout isnrsquot a bad one, and could instil some confidence for future changes.ldquoWhat I would question is whether the timing is right so soon after businesses have reopened.Five hundred people have responded to the town council survey so far.Cllr Nigel Humphrey - for St Augustines - said: ldquoPeople have been responding to the survey asit is a done deal, when in fact it is intended as part of a constructive dialogue about the future of our town centre."Gideon Calder of Gwyrddio Penarth Greeningsaid: ldquoFrom conversations with people, some are assuming that the current arrangement in the town centre ndash the bollards and one-way system ndash is the same thing as these alternative ideas about creating safer space."In fact these plans are quite dferent. continue providing expert paediatric palliative care to le-limited children as well as memory-making activity to help make the childrenrsquos short lives as full as possible.Since going into lockdown Whatever he thinks or feels about Isreal is his opinion but this should not overspill onto Jewish people.mdash DJ SPOONYJuly , The posts have been widely condemned, and Twitter has come under fire for allowing them to remain visible for more than  hours after they were first posted. A number of tweets have now been removed.Grime producer DJ Spoony said the comments were ldquoat best inflammatory and at worst criminal in some aspects.He wrote on Twitter: ldquoIrsquom a very proud black man who has genuine love for everyone however wrong is wrong. Irsquom not going to publicly lsquohangrsquo him. Education is the only way to battle bigotry in any form.He encouraged members of the Jewish community to message Wiley to help him see ldquothe error of his ways.We unequivocally condemn Wileyrsquos antisemitic comments. @wileyceo received The Ivors Inspiration Award in  for his musical contribution to grime in the early s.We stand against all forms of intolerance. Northern Irish sheddie Trevor Carswell, , is through to the finals of the  Cuprinol Shed Of The YearHe said: “It was built using salvaged items and most of the objects inside are keepsake memoirs collected over the years. The cabin displays my children’s first pair of welly boots and primary school paintings, family photos, travel souvenirs and antiques from bygone days. “For me, this makes the space quite sentimental and a special place to spend time with friends and family. “As an avid outdoor family we have always appreciated our garden, but have felt particularly fortunate to have this space to enjoy during lockdown. The shed has been used as a place to relax and unwind during these uncertain times. It has provided the perfect backdrop for family barbecues, nights by the fire and a cosy getaway during the long unprecedented days.”The competition sees  competitors battling for the crown across nine categories. A youth Assembly is a fantastic setting to encourage debate and allow our young people to opportunity to hold their elected representatives to account.
